sec.div: Minimum inhibitory concentration/minimum fungicidal concentration of Origanum vulgare
sec.p: After the antifungal action the essential oil was established, the research was continued to determine the MIC/MFC using serial dilution method. Serial dilution method for determination of MIC and MFC of the herbal oils have been implemented by Chitwood[ 33] and Johnson (2008)[ 34] and it was found to be satisfactory to use in laboratories. Furthermore, according to the NCCLS standards, it is an efficient method to evaluate MIC/MFC of the antifungal agents.[ 35] In the present study, the MIC of O. vulgare was found to be 0.024% and MFC was observed as 0.097% [ Table 2] when it was tested against Candida. In a study by Manohar et al.,[ 17] the authors showed that O. vulgare can be fungicidal on C. albicans from mice with a MIC of 0.125% and MFC of 0.25%. In their study, they also observed that a daily dose of 1.0 Î¼l of O. vulgare oil for 30 days can cure systemic candidiasis in mice.

We compared the MIC/MFC of O. vulgare with existing value for fluconazole (0.25%)[ 36] and it was observed that the MIC/MFC of O. vulgare (0.024% and 0.097%) was much lower. The MIC of O. vulgare (0.024%) which was determined in our study is in par with a study carried out by Hammer et al.,[ 37] wherein it was found to be 0.03% against C. albicans. In a study by Xu et al.,[ 38] MIC of fluconazole was found to be 125 times more in azole-resistant C. albicans than in susceptible C. albicans. The present experimental herb O. vulgare showed much lesser MIC/MFC as compared to fluconazole indicating that the herb can be effective even in a lower dose of MIC/MFC. In a comparative study by Lambert et al.,[ 39] they also observed that O. vulgare had a total inhibitory effect on the pathogens involved. However, their study was against bacteria and not the fungi affecting human beings.

Comparison of the MIC/MFC results obtained in the present study with earlier studies available may not be reliable, as the composition of the essential oil used in the present study could be different from those used in the previous studies. It is known that the composition of an essential oil can vary according to the local climatic and environmental situations and the time of harvesting the herb.[ 40 41] Furthermore, there are no comparable studies on effect of O. vulgare on human oral isolates from denture stomatitis patients, as the present study is the first of its kind in the literature.
